Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Concerns about maintaining a strong, vibrant US economy and improving global competitiveness have led to efforts to increase the number and diversity of graduates in STEM majors. Attrition among engineering students is high in the first two years of college studies, and even higher among women and underrepresented minority students. There have been research investments made by multiple stakeholders that have invested in various strategies to improve the situation with many efforts focused on knowledge-acquisition aspects of student performance. In contrast there are research efforts to explore strategies that are more focused on motivation and self-regulatory aspects of student performance. There has been an increasing effort to investigate a construct that measures these aspects called grit. Grit, which is defined as unwavering interest in and perseverance for a long-term goal, is likely to be important to individuals trying to achieve the challenging, long-term goal of attaining an engineering degree.

The proposed study is an active learning model that evaluates the impacts on grit character trait and its relations to student retention in engineering. It will be conducted with an ethnically and economically diverse sample of undergraduate engineering students. The team is using an experimental design approach in which response to the control groups is utilized to evaluate grit characteristics of growth mindset and build optimism. The research questions seek to investigate if active learning builds the character trait of grit among engineering students while they learn in a sequence of engineering mechanics courses and whether increased grit leads to other success outcomes such as retention in the major and progress toward degree. The intellectual merit includes the treatment approach to explore active learning impacts on student grit upon student retention and course sequencing. The broader impacts of research is that an active learning design model that can provide insights to the impact on student retention and completion of coursework and degree completion. Also there will be special focus on investigating women and underrepresented minorities who leave STEM majors at disproportionately higher rates in the STEM workforce.

This project is supported by NSFs EHR Core Research Program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grit -- defined as a consistency of interest and a relentless pursuit of a long-term goal -- is a noncognitive factor that is associated with student success and achievement. It is believed that a necessary factor for building grit is deliberate practice, which itself is defined as oft-repeated practice designed to improve performance and accompanied by useful feedback. In this project focused on mechanical engineering undergraduates, we test the hypothesis that active learning is a proxy for deliberate practice and that the more engaged a student is with learning, the better the performance.

Active learning requires students to do meaningful and engaged learning activities, and to think about what they are doing while engaged in the designed activities. It is not simply the quantity of such learning but also its quality, which we define as the cognitive demand that it places on students. To measure this quality we adopt the interactive-constructive-active-passive (ICAP) differentiated learning activities framework. The ICAP framework classifies learning activities by observable, overt actions of the learner. A passive learning activity is one in which the learner essentially engages in no overt actions. Listening to a lecture, watching a video, and reading text are examples. By contrast, an active learning activity is characterized by overt actions that demonstrate paying attention. Examples include note taking or highlighting of text. If the learner goes one step further and generates additional knowledge or information beyond that which is provided, she is engaging in constructive learning. Solving homework problems alone or resolving questions while reviewing notes alone are examples of this. The final category of interactive learning requires learners to interact with someone (e.g., a peer or expert) or something (e.g., a computer tutor) so as to build on the provided information. There must be an exchange of information between the members, such as defending one's responses, responding to questions, or correcting noted errors. The conventionally accepted active-learning techniques would be classified as either constructive or interactive in the ICAP framework. Furthermore, based on the possible underlying cognitive mechanisms being activated by each kind of activity, the expected learning gains should increase in the order of passive < active < constructive < interactive; this is supported by previous studies. It is also reasonable to expect that cognitive demand increases in the same order and that constructive and interactive learning would rise to the level of "mentally demanding" required in deliberate practice. 

While we have not completed our data analyses from over 4+ years of data collection, and thus we cannot yet conclusively answer the research question posed, we have achieved other notable outcomes. To measure both the quantity and quality of a student's engagement with learning, we developed a smartphone application (or "app") that the user uses to track learning at the individual student level. This app, called Actively Learning, is available for both the Android and iOS operating systems and has been thoroughly tested for robustness and reliability over several years. We have tested its accuracy of data collection and demonstrated its usefulness in demonstrating students' study habits and patterns. We have also demonstrated its uniqueness among various other research tools designed to measure learning engagement. These features were crucial in an unexpected and tangential study that resulted from the abrupt shift to online, remote learning imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic. We hope to continue the development of this app in the future by changing it from a research tool to a student-support tool that gives feedback to students of their learning engagement, tips to manage stress and anxiety, and evidence based study strategies.
